div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Service Maritime Roumain
div.p: 16 Rue Sesostris 16

Par suite de la quarantaine de 48 houres imposée par la Turquie aux provenances d'Egypte les paquebots-poste du Service Maritime Roumain quitteront Alexandrie chaque quinzaine le Mercredi à 4 heures de l'après midi. Au cas où cette quarantaine serait réduite à 24 heures seulement les départs auront lieu le Jeudi à 4 p.m.
Alexandrie, le 25 Juin 1907.

div.head: THE STORM-SWEPT BALKANS.
div.p: Mr. Fisher Unwin has just published a new work on the Near East, which gives us some interesting side-lights on the present position of affairs in the Balkan Peninsula. The author, who witholds his identity on the ground that much of the information given to him was of a confidential nature, and because the work contains "many plain truths and much out spoken criticism," apparently had every oppor tunity of studying the situation first-hand. He was the bearer of despatches from the British Government and had introductions which obtained for him audiences of the kings and princes of the Balkan states, the Sultan of Turkey, and the highest officials in various cabinets. At the outset he makes the frank confession that "the writer who attempts to place the various Balkan questions impartially and clearly before the public will at once find himself utterly confused, and wallowing wildly in a morass of roisstatement and misrepresenta tion. The Balkans torn by race-hatreds, party strife, and the intrigues of the Powers." This accurate description of the position in the storin-swept Peninsula is followed up by the equally frank statement that "much that w's told me in one country was contradicted in the next," so that, even for an observer who had so free an entry to the inner circles of diplomacy, the difficulties of getting at the truth were anything but slight. The writer visited in turn Montenegro, Northern Albania, Dalmatia, Bosnia, Herzegovina, Servia, Bulgaria, Rou mania, Turkey, and Macedonia, and he gives as a vivid description of the unrest and race feuds everywhere prevalent.' Austria and Ger many figure throughout the book as dominat ing and sinister influences. The author bluntly accuses the two powers of competing for the supremacy in the Balkans. "The Austrian Eagle has overshadowed and grasped Bosnia, she has ber talons into Servia, and is casting covetous glances upon gallant little Monte negro." Germany, on the other hand, is pursu ing her rôle of Defender of the Faithful to such a successful degree that her influence at Yildiz is paramount, and the tragedy of Macedonia is quietly ignored. Austria is de nounced for adopting "Russian" methods in order to bring about the subjugation of Bosnia. The peasantry are oppressed, and subject to an elaborate system of 'espionage, and the liberty of the press is unknown. Austria, we are further told, is also responsible for the adverse criticisms of King Peter's rule in Servià which have appeared in the London press, the correspondents being in the pay of the Austrian Government.
This seems very astonishing, but not inore so than the author's fattery of King Peter, who is held up to us as a patriot without guile.

Both Servia and Bulgaria, it is interest ing to note, are anxious for British capital to be introduced in order to exploit their mineral resources, and bona fide applications for concessions are welcomed. The author says that from information which he gather ed the opinion seemed to be unanimo's that the troubles still existing between Bulgaria and Turkey over Macedonia are in no way decreasing, but rather the contrary, and he goes so far as to predict that war is inevitable batween these two countries, and that hostilities will probably break out before the end of the year. An important factor in the situation, he says, is Roumania. "Bulgurią cannot attack Turkey without Roumania's" consent, and this

will only be given "on condition that if Bulgaria, as the result of the war, annexes any Macedonian territory, then she should cede to Roumania that portion of her territory lying between the Danube and the Black Sea, taking a line from a little east of Varna. Such a condition is certainly not to be viewed in Bulgaria with any satisfaction, yet as its acceptance wonld mean the extension of Bulgaria to the Adriatic, the settlement of the Macedonian question, and the final destruction of Turkey as a power in Europe, the Bulgarian Cabinet are considering it very carefully." This seems a very ambi- tious programme, with regard to the execution of which the European powers might reasonably be expected to have something to say. The Sultan and the high officials view the outlook with their usual philosophical calm. The writer's opinion is that Turkey is uncertain of the attitude of Servia and Roumania, and is rather mystified as to what Austria will in the event of war. Relying upon Germany, and treating Great Britain with studied politeness, she views the present critical situation with perfect indifference." The prospect is anything but reassuring. We are given a terrible picture of wholesale massacres, and the latest informa- tion to hand shows that the "reforms" have done little to check the operations of the Greek bands, who are spreading misery and death in all directions. What will be the end of it all is difficult to forecast. Sir Edward Grey the other day received an influential deputation headed by the Arch- bishop of Canterbary, who urged the necessity of European control in Macedonia, but he could give them but cold comfort. He had to admit that in spite of what had been done to restore order the condition of things in Macedonia remained much the same as before, and the situation was now complicated by internecine warfare. The proposal that a Euro- pean Governor-General should be appointed he considered impracticable. To attempt to secure it by isolated action on the part of Great Britain would result in international complica tions. This is obviously the fact, and the other members of the Concert would naturally resent any attempt at individual action by the British Government, were such action possible. It now remains to be seen whether the increase of the Customs dues will bring about any better supervision of this unhappy country, and we await with interest the proposals for reform which Austria and Russia are expected to make in the course of the present summer. Professor Agoura, of Sofia University, suggest ed to the author that the best settlement would be a restrained autonomy, that would not separate Macedoins from Turkey. Macedonia. should be placed under a European Governor- General, preferably a Swiss, in whom the central administration should be vested, all other questions being left to Turkey. The book contains much information regarding the economic condition of the countries under survey, and is illustrated by a number of excel- lent photographs by the author and Princess Zenia of Montenegro.
("An Observer in the Near East". 1. Fisher Unwin.)

div.head: EASTERN TELEGRAPH CO. LTD.
div.p: AVERAGE TIME occupied in transmission of Egyptian telegrams from England to Alexandria on Tuesday, 11th July, 1905.
OUTWARDS.
Between the hours of 10 a.m. and 6 p.m. (Cairo time)

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: Greece has imposed three days' quarantine against arrivals from Alexandria.

div.head: Cairo Police Budget,
div.p: 5 thefts, II misdemeanors and 44 minor offences were recorded in Cairo and its suburbs on Wednesday.

div.head: The Cotton Position.
div.p: We particulary invite the attention of our readers to to-morrow's cotton review, which will contain a full diagnosis of the position.

div.head: Sale of Steamer.
div.p: The Moss liner "Tabor," built in 1890, since when she has run chiefly between Liverpool and Alexandria, has recently been sold to Danish shipowners.

div.head: Pigeon Shooting.
div.p: On Sunday next another pigeon shooting establishment is to be inaugurated at Alexandria. It is situated in the Champs Elysées. The proceedings will begin at 2.30 p.m.

div.head: Attempted Burglary.
div.p: Yesterday evening at about 4 a.m. the secret police arrested a Greek while he was attempting to force an entrance into a shop in Sharia Nubar Pasha. He refused to give his name and it is believed that he is an old offender, named Carungas.

div.head: Poisoned by Verdigris.
div.p: A mason, named Ali Mansour, and his wife, living in Sharia Kasr-el Shok, Cairo, were suddenly seized with terrible internal pains, and, on a medical examination being made, it was covered that they were suffering from verdigris poisoning owing to their having prepared their meals in a dirty copper pan. Their condition is very serious.

div.head: Ministry of Public Works.
div.p: By ministerial decree, dated 11th July, Mr. R. Maitland, chief inspector, will undertake the duties of Controller General of the Sanitary Department during the absence on leave of Mr. Carkeet James, and during the absence of Mr. Maitland, who leaves for Europe shortly on a special mission, Mr. A. Pinson will will assume his duties.

div.head: Fatal Accident,
div.p: About 5 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon, a portion of wall of the Greek church in Darb Guinena, Cairo, fell in, burying a young native girl, named Anna bint Mohamed, in the debris. When she was eventually extracted, life was found to be extinct, and the body was conveyed to the home of her parents in the Taht el Raba quarter.

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: 528 births, of which 9 were of European parentage, and 837 deaths, of which 19 were Europeans, were registered in Cairo during the week ending 15th inst. 669 of the deaths were of children under 5 years of age. The following epidemics are cited as the principal causes of death dyphtheria 7, typhus 16, typhoid 3, measles 79, small pox 1 and erysipelas 4.

div.head: A Dishonest Servant.
div.p: Mohamed Bey Arif, of Helouan, complained to the police that he had been robbed of a bank note worth L.E. 50 and that he suspected one of his servants of having taken it. The latter was arrested and her house searched, when various objects belonging to her master, and valued at considerably more than the above mentioned sum, were discovered. She eventually admitted her crime.

div.head: Cheap Egyptian Mummy.
div.p: The quaintest among a crowd of curious things on sale at Stevenson's room in Covent Garden, London, last week, was a tall wooden case painted all over with curious hieroglyphics in which rested the mummy of an Egyptian princess. Despite the fact that the mummy is believed to be more than 3,400 years old, and is one of the very few perfect specimens still remaining outside the museums, it failed to attract the attention of any notable Egyptologists, and after a languid bidding was knocked down for the sum of thirteen guineas.

div.head: Land at Omdurman.
div.p: The auction sale of building sites offered by the Government at Omdurman took place on the 8th inst. at Omdurman zaptieh. Eight leasehold sites were offered in the "suk," and bids for these went up high. As much as £1 per sq. metre was the average premium paid for these sites. Evidently the purchasers needed the sites for their business and had no speculation in view. The freehold sites offered at the Mulazimin quarter realized about 10 or 12 P.T. per square metre, which is not very bad, considering the extent of territory at Omdurman that is available for building sites.

div.head: THE VIVANTE MYSTERY,
div.p: The Vivante mystery appears to be no nearer solution than on the day on which the body of the deceased was discovered in a bedroom of the hotel. According to the latest information obtained almost at the moment of going to press, the Spanish Consul, Hopkinson Bey, and Hachem Bey visited about half past one this afternoon the room where the body was discovered, and made a minute investigation of all that had taken place on the night of the murder or suicide, whichever it may be, paying special attention to the occupation of the neighbouring room by the jeweller previously mentioned. Both the proprietor of the hotel and the jeweller were questioned minutely, but we understand that no information further than that obtained in the first instance was forthcoming. We understand that no further clue has resulted from the investigations of the police.

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S MEMORIAL.
ANGLO-EGYPTIAN INDIFFERENCE
div.p: Considerable attention has been drawn by the foreign and native local Press to the letter of Mr. R.J. Moss, which recently appeared in our columns on the subject of the attitude of the members of the Anglo-Egyptian Colony at Alexandria to the question of a memorial to Lord Cromer. Out of one thousand circulars letters addressed to British residents in Alexandria asking for their opinion as to the form the testimonial to Lord Cromer should take, only 29 replies were received.

The facts given in Mr. Moss's letter admit of only one interpretation, which is that the persons to whom the letters were adressed were so indifferent to the matter that they never took the trouble to give any thought to them. This attitude of indifference is deserving of notice, because the British Colony at Alexandria is the most important non-official section of Anglo-Egyptians in the country. They represent the permanent section of the English population of Egypt far more than the Anglo- Egyptian official inhabitants of Cairo. It would therefore be thought that here, if anywhere, such an appeal as that made by Mr. Moss would have been readily responded to. The appeal, however, failed completely in its object. One local contemporary in drawing attention to this interesting fact remarks "Sie transit gloria mundi." Another contemporary enunciates the following theory for this indifference :-

It appears that the English Colony are not of the same opinion as their heads, or are not satisfied with the pioneers of the occupation. With the object of erecting a monument to the memory of Lord Cromer, one of these addressed a circular to 130 of his compatriots and only received 29 answers to his appear. We have looked for the reasons for this ill-feeling towards Lord Cromer and his policy. The English Colony did not enjoy the consideration which extended by their authorities towards the various European Colonies, Italian, French, and German. The English nation is represented in Egypt by Government officials to the exclusion of the colonists to such a point that Lord Cromer imported the employés directly from England. English business men have not found in Egypt the help which they hoped for. These are the reasons which made them hate the Cromerian administration.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM.
SECRET SOCIETIES.
div.p: "Al-Watan" says:-

A case will in all probability be brought before the native tribunal at one of the centres of Upper Egypt in which the hand of secret societies is bound to appear. It will be remembered that the principal aim of these societies is to boycott British goods in general. Our friends of the Nationalist party hastened to refute our news whenever we published a line on this subject; but they let the cat out of the bag last month when they enjoined upon their Mohamedan brethren in the columns of "Al- Lewa" to buy no goods from foreigners and take all they require "from their brother even if his goods were bad and dear." This fact was pointed out by us at the time when "Al-Lewa" attempted a lame explanation that did not satisfy its own supports. Now that a law-suit is pending with the boycotting of foreign goods by two members of a secret society as its raison d'être it will be hard, even for "Al-Lewa" to explain the matter away. We hope to give more details on this law-suit and the working of secret societies on a future date. The Cairo correspondent of the "Pall Mall Gazette" agrees with us that the frequency of complaints and accusations and, the evident pains to which the Nationalist Press has gone in every instance to refute them, show that they are not ill-founded. Our able contemporary will, no doubt, find additional proofs in the open letter published by "Al-Lewa" to which we have referred and in the coming law-suit which we are promised in a few days. We in our turn, agree with the correspondent of the "Pall Mall Gazette" that the Government is fully informed of what is happening and that its secret service men are distributed all over the country. But in certain cases these secret agents are utterly useless, either from wanton duplicity or from crass imbecility. Morcover, the proverbial indifference and inaction of our Government in all matters connected with the anti-English movement have assumed alarming proportions. If the London Press well help to move our authorities to action in these questions a great danger may be smothered before it grows too tough.

div.head: CUSTOMS RETURNS.
div.p: According to the Customs Returns for June last the total value of imports during that month amounted to L.E. 1,892,152 and the exports to L.E. 1,180,744 against LE. 1,645,913 and L.E. 940,588 respectively during the corresponding month of last year. The total imports and exports from the beginning of the year up to the end of June were L.E. 12,286,183 and L.E. 13,242,405 against L.E. 10,513,579 and L.E. 11,154,660 for the corresponding six months of 1906, During the month under review specie to the amount of L.E. 511,796 was imported and L E. 638,063 exported against L.E. 41,512 and L.E. 675,945 for June 1906.

The total imports and exports of specie during the first six months of 1907 amounted to L.E. 2,010,427 and L.E. 638,163 against L.E. 591,444 and L.E. 675,945 respectively for the corresponding half year of 1906.

div.head:
THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
THE CRISIS AND THE COTTON CROP.
div.p: Under the above heading "C.R." has in a recent issue of "La Reforme" discussed the position of the coming staple export crop of Egypt with reference to the cultivator, the export buyer, the speculator, and the banker; and the conclusion at which he arrives is what we should have expected from any one inoculated with the financial heresies of "La Reforme," viz: "that, the time has arrived for the Government to intervene and place at the disposal of the National Bank sufficient funds to enable that institution to make large advances etc. etc." but our contemporary's nostrum, so frequently prescribed, and now adopted by 'C.R.,' is too well known to require completion.

On this occasion the appeal is more earnest than ever and the Government are solemnly warned that if they fail to apply the prescription of La Reforme then "the fellah's interests will suffer cruelly and the crisis will become, frightfully acute and general; the striken fellah will fall into arrears in the payment of his taxes" and at the culmination of this disaster the very credit of the Government itself may be shaken!! From this appalling picture we turn to a consideration of the conditions of the cotton cultivation in Egypt which "C.R." has clearly and accurately set forth and while the conclusions at which we have arrived are very different, we claim to have given the subject as serious consideration as "C.R." has done, and to have consulted the opinions of those we consider most entitled to respect.

We find the situation calls for the exercise of prudence and judgment, but we fail to see any occasion for alarm or fear that the business capacity of the exporters engaged in the cotton trade will prove inadequate to financing the crop without prejudice to the interest of the fellah and without upsetting the money market.

It is unnecessary to follow "C.R." into his explanation of the modus operandi by which exporters, who sell ahead of the season to spinners abroad, cover their sales by contract purchases against fluctuations of the market.
His explanation is perfectly lucid and any one of our readers who is unacquainted with the operation will do well to study the explanation given on the subject in "La Réforme" of the 15th inst.

From the comments of "C.R." we might be led to believe that exporters of cotton are compelled this year to cover their sales abroad by purchase of contracts, owing to insufficiency of funds to purchase in the country from the fellaheen, and it is on this point especially that we join issue with "C.R." as we believe him to be entirely misinformed.
It appears to us that he has jumped to this conclusion owing to the recent exposure of some of the difficulties which confront the exporters in covering their sales by contracts.

Of course it is impossible for the exporters to cover in the interior, during the summer months, the large sales made abroad as promptly as during the cotton season, hence recourse to contracts purchased on the bourse for temporary cover of their sales: and what has occurred this year in the way of purchase of contracts is in no way singular, but merely what is done every year, though perhaps to a larger extent this year, because, as "C.R." remarks, forward sales have been very heavy.
It is generally estimated that one third of the coming crop has already been sold, a great part of which has been purchased or engaged from the fellaheen and the balance covered by contract.

Any difficulty that the exporter may experience arises from the fact that brokers, knowing the enormous losses made by speculators, are unwilling to deal in contracts. But "C.R." apparently fails to realise that, at this period of the year, cotton shippers have much, if not most, of their own capital free and hence have very little need of recourse to the local banks for assistance. Now as to the cultivator, so far from the fellah being the object of our sympathy, we are inclined to regard him with feelings akin to envy.

The Government by the guarantee of a further sum of one million sterling has enabled the Agricultural Bank to increase its working capital to that extent during the past few months, which sum is available for the cultivator, and this favoured individual can dispose of his crop if he so desires at $20 per cantar resulting in a profit of anything up to 100% on his outlay. And it is on his behalf that the Government are invited to place huge sums of gold with the National Bank of Egypt Ld., in order to enable him to pay his taxes and so save the credit of the Government itself!!!
We think that we have made it evident that the position of the felaheen need cause anxiety neither to the Government nor to any one else.

The individual whose position is actually precarious is the speculative seller of cotton, whose calculations of lower prices have been completely upset by the poor prospects of the American crop and the consequent advance in the price of Egyptian, and it is in his interest that the recent decision of the Committee of the Bourse is being engineered. But even if the speculative spirit be paralysed and exporters be unable to purchase contracts for futures, we fail to see how the cotton trade of the country can be ultimately damaged. The fellah will either sell his crop at a fixed price for forward delivery, or he will wait until it has been marketed. Probably in fear that a glut may occur if he waits too long he will sell forward.

As regards financing, the crop is virtually financed by the spinners whether British, American or Continental, the accomodation extended by the banks here being merely of a temporary nature and quickly repaid by the exporters. Last year owing to the early and heavy arrivals of the crop, and to its unexpected value, the Banks found themselves unprepared for the demand made on the stock of gold which they had provided: but there is little fear of any such state of unpreparedness this year. We have every reason to believe that a larger stock of gold exists in the vaults of the Banks in Egypt to-day, than at any previous period: and this hoarding is not for the luxury of the thing, but to provide for all contingencies of every nature whatever.
The large export houses too, have carefully scrutinised and forecasted the position, and we feel confident that nothing has been left to chance which can be controlled by prudence and forethought.

We understand "C.R.'s" assertion to be that bills drawn in Egypt are at present viewed askance in European centres, but this cannot possibly refer to cotton transactions, for the capital of the exporters is intact. They have enjoyed a prosperous year and their credit never stood higher than to-day in consequence.

The fellaheen's wealth is greater this year than last and the value of land, his only investment, is not depreciated: Therefore the condition of the cotton business is sufficiently sound all round for no cause of any anxiety.

It is in no censorious spirit that we have dealt with "C.R.'s" remarks for we believe them to be the honest outcome of careful investigation. None the less we do believe his conclusions to be erroneous and to be fraught with danger, inasmuch as they may be read and accepted abroad, being shielded under the aegis of our respected contemporary "La Reforme." We consider that unnecessarily alarmist reports and reiterated appeals to the Government for unnecessary aid are calculated to damage Egyptian credit and to counteract these mischievous if honest appeals we shall continue to direct our untiring energies.

div.head:
MINISTRY OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION.
THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.
div.p: The Paris "Temps" publishes an article concerning the resignation of M. Lambert, a Frenchman, from the directorate of the Khedivial School of Law.

After calling in question the qualifications of Mr. Hill, the Englishman by whom M. Lambert has been superseded, the "Temps" says: "The supplanting of a Frenchman by an Englishman is correct according to the letter of the law, but it is not very just, friendly, or clever. It is not just, because the School of Law is an essentially French institution: not friendly, as being contrary to the mutual engagements between France and Great Britain, and to the agreement of April 8th, 1904; not clever, since the decision is not in consonance with the general trend of British policy."

The "Temps" asserts that what it describes as "the vexations" of Mr. Dunlop drove M. Lambert to resign, and goes on to urge favoured treatment for the French in Egypt, who represent considerable material and moral interests. "The mutual confidence which characterises Anglo-French relations," it concludes, "impels us to say quite frankly that there is no justification, no explanation, and no excuse for the treatment inflicted on us by officials of the Dunlop school."

The following telegram has been sent to M. Pichon, Minister of Foreign Affairs, Paris, by Messrs. Caneri and Vaast, deputies of the French Nation:" Not only as regards ourselves personally, but in the name of the whole French Colony in Cairo, we wish it to be brought to your notice that we cannot agree with the opinions expressed by Sir Edward Grey in the House of Commons on July 16 as regards the Affaire Lambert and the directorship of the Khedivial School of Law at Cairo. We express our wish that the post in question be allotted to a Frenchman. The entente cordiale will be void of any real signification unless our interests in Egypt be provided for.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: Our Army and Navy correspondent writes from London:- According to present arrangements, the 1st Battalion of the Alexandria Princess of Wales's Own Yorkshire Regiment, familiarly known as the "Green Howards," will embark on the S.S. "Soudan," at Southampton, about the 16th January for Alexandria, Egypt. The battalion, which will relieve the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers at Cairo, will detach one company for duty in Cyprus. The "Soudan" will also carry out various drafts and details for Gibraltar, Malta and Egypt. The Green Howards were in the Soudan Frontier operations of 1884, and participated in the action of Giniss. Lieutenant Colonel E. M. Esson, who now commands the battalion, was then a subaltern of the battalion.

In some recent instructions issued by the Army Council in regard to the procedure to be adopted in carrying out reliefs, it is pointed out that in years past the non-commissioned officers posted in relief to the service units abroad have, in some cases, been very young soldiers, who on joining their units have found themselves senior in rank to non commissioned offices of greater experience and length of service. The Council has directed that in selecting reliefs officers in charge of records are to send out non-commissioned officers of more equal length of service and seniority, so far as it is possible to do this without detriment to the requirements of units at home.

div.head: BRITISH FLEET'S VISIT.
div.p: The British Fleet has come and gone, and those few officers who were privileged to spend a few days on Troodos will doubtless regret that their stay could not have been longer. The majority of the officers being unable to visit the mountain station, preferred, and wisely so, to remain mostly on board ship, landing only for a little walking or riding exercise.

The Bluejackets can have found little to attract them on land, as at this time of year no entertainments could be arranged for their amusement. Certainly the pleasantest hours out of the twenty four must at this season of the year be those spent in bathing, and very thoroughly did they seem to enjoy it, prolonging their aquatic exercises well through the afternoons..

H.M.S. 'Venerable' and H.M.S. 'Prince of Wales' have been anchored in these roadsteads, the former being the Flagship of Rear-Admiral H.R.H. Prince Louis of Battenberg. The Prince is already well known in this town where he is highly popular, and where his commanding presence and affable manners have won for him the admiration and the good opinion of all the inhabitants.
The bands of both vessels came on shore and played selections of music in the afternoons, much to the delight and appreciation of the townspeople.

div.head: Ice Supply.
div.p: Much trouble and inconvenience has been caused to residents in the chief towns by the sudden cessation last week of the ice deliveries from the new ice factory here, due we believe, to a temporary breakdown in the machinery. The ice was in good demand and those who had become accustomed to its use have felt the deprivation severely. The usual consignments of snow from the Troodos 'snowpits' had this year been stopped in order that the new ice venture might not be unduly interfered with, and Nicosia residents are therefore not able even to fall back on that alternative. We hope the production and delivery of ice will soon be recommenced.

div.head: Personal.
div.p: Mr. H. A. Smallwood, Island Treasurer, has just accepted the appointment of Treasurer of St. Lucia, and he is expected to leave Cyprus with his wife and family early in October.

Mr. Oscar Heidenstein, Inspector of Military Police in Cyprus, eldest son of Dr. Heidenstein, C.M.G., chief medical officer for the Island, has also received promotion, having received a police appointment in Uganda. He is proceeding by this mail to England, for the purpose of undergoing a course of special training before taking up his new duties.

Mr. F. Ney, who had been headmaster of the English school, Nicosia, since December last, is leaving for England this week. We understand that he has accepted a similar appointment in Bishop Blyth's schools, Cairo, and will be proceeding to Egypt this autumn. The Rev. Cooke-Collis-Smith, who is vacating the Chaplaincy of the Anglican Church in Nicosia, is leaving for England by this week's mail boat.
Miss Biddulph, sister of Lady King Harman, who has been on a visit to this Island of some months' duration, is returning to England this week.

div.head: THE CHATBY ESPLANADE.
div.p: According to a note received by the Municipality on the subject of the projected esplanade from Fort Silsileh to Mustapha from Mr. Lloyd Davies, chief engineer, it is impossible to criticise in detail the project from the construction point of view, but taking it from the general point of an engineer the plan is well laid out and there is no question as to its practicability. It would, indeed, greatly improve the coast from Fort Silsileh to Mustapha. Mr. Lloyd Davies sees no technical objection to the project, but suggests that the plans should be subjected to the Municipality before the concession is granted, and that the work should be conducted under its supervision

div.head: COTTON WORM.
div.p: The following is the report of the Ministry of the Interior on the cotton worm during the week ended the 11th instant :-
The provinces of Assiout, Beni Souef, Fayoum, Minia and Kena remained immune.
In Behera, 26,957 feddans in 221 villages were infected and 22,368 cleared.
In Dakahlia 1879 feddans in 90 villages were infected and 1529 cleared.
In Gharbieh, 1159 feddans in 40 villages were infected and 1086 cleared.
In Ghiza 552 feddans in 6 villages were infected and 44 cleared.
In Menoufia 1248 feddans in 37 villages were infected and cleared.
In Kaliubieh 2284 feddans in 115 villages were infected and cleared.
In the Sharkia 1023 feddans in 18 villages were infected and cleared

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Persian Prince" with passengers and general cargo, left London on the 18th inst. and will arrive at Alexandria on or about the 4th August.
The Ellerman liner "Avon" sailed on Wednesday from Liverpool for Swansea, Malta and Alexandria with a general cargo.
The S S. "Indian Prince" arrived Manchester on the 16th inst. from Alexandria via Malta.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Governor of Cairo is among the latest arrivals at Bad Nauheim.
Boghos Pasha Nubar is staying at the Carlton Hotel, London.

Grafton Bey presented a pair of gold bracelets and Mr. and Mrs. A. Grafton, of Alexandria, gave a silk Persian rug on the occasion of the marriage last week at St. Mary's Church, Bedford, of Miss Beatrice Louise, daughter of Mr. Grafton, A.M.I.C E., and Mrs. Grafton, of Cardingtonroad, Bedford, to Mr. William Edmond Beaves, eldest son of the late Mr. Thomas W. Beaves, and Mrs. Beaves; of Muswell Hill, London. The bride's father is the respected proprietor of the Vulcan Works, and Mrs. Grafton is popular as a lady Guardian of the Poor and in other useful walks of Bedford life. There was a crowded congregation and very great interest was shown in the happy event.

Major W. H. H. Persse, Queen's Bays, who for the past ten years has been attached to the Egyptian Army, and latterly commanding the the cavalry of the Khedive, has been ordered to join the details of his regiment attached to the Reserve Squadron of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, Ballincollig, by the 6th prox. Major Persse is the senior major of the regiment, and under the recent regulations must serve two years regimetally before he can be appointed to the command. He had a distinguished career in the Khedive's service, and the very efficient state in which he leaves the Egyptian cavalry is a monument to this energy. Whilst in Egypt, he participated in every campaign fought in the Soudan, etc., including the Dongola Ex- pedition, 1896 (mentioned in despatches, medal with clasp, and 4th class Medjidieh), Nile Expedition, 1897 (clasp), Nile Expedition, 1898, in which he was wounded, and the battles of Atbara and Omdurman (Mentioned twice in despatches, brevet majority, two clasps, British medal).

div.p: Nous rappelons que dimanche prochain aura lieu au Casino San Stefano, le premier concert vocal et instrumental, en plein air. Il y aura de même projections cinématographiques de 7 à 8 heures.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi). La baisse continue sans interruption, sous 'avalanche croissante des offres de vente. A mesure que les prix fléchissent, de nouveaux létenteurs se voient pris dans l'engrenage et, encore une fois, il est impossible de prévoir exactement où s'arrêtera la déroute. C'est panique qu'il faudrait dire, car l'ensemble de la spéculation ne raisonne plus. On vend m!me De qu'on n'a pas. Il est acquis, en effet, que beaucoup vendent le jour même ce qu'ils espè rent racheter le lendemain à meilleur compte, et l'opération leur réussit à merveille. C'est pour cela qu'ils sont embarrassés de livrer im médiatement à leurs achetenrs. Il nous semble, pour prévenir cet abus, que les acquéreurs tevraient insister sur la livraison immédiate on annuler l'opération. De cette façon les ven deurs en blanc, risquant trop de garder les titres pour compte, ne voudraient plus se livrer & une combinaison aussi hasardeuse.

D'autre part, il est clair que les détenteurs de valeurs en sont à jouer leur dernier carte. A délant d'autres titres aisément négociables, ils se voient obligés de se défaire des obligations Crédit Foncier, anciennes et nouvelles. C'est la seule explication plausible à la dégringolade rapide de ces obligations qui s'inscrivent au jourd'hui à 285 l'ancienne et 251 la nouvelle, en perte respective de 9 et 4 francs. Pour en arriver là il faut que l'épargne soit forcée dans jes derniers retranchements.

Les valeurs dirigeantes sont pourtant assez soutenues, l'Agricole à 7 1/2 et la National Bank à 18 1/2 ; la Delta Light bénéficie même le 1/8 à 9 7/16; mais, comme affairesp il n'y en 2 guère ea qu'en Agricole.
Les fléchissements les plus notables sont 15 fr, sur les Dividendes Tramways à 275,1/2 livre sur les Nungovich Hotels à 14, 8 livres sur la Nile Land à 12, 1/2 livre sur la Land In: vestment à 3 1/2.
En baisse également la Ramleh Railway de 1.11/16.8 4 1/2, les Tramways d'Alexandrie de 138 à 137, les Lots Turcs de 165 à 164, la Land Bank de 6 7/8 à 6 3/4, l'Urbaine de 3 5/8
3 9/16, le Comptoir de 2 1/2 l'ancienne et 2 1/8 la nouvelle à 2 1,8 et 2 respectivement, la Building Lands de 2 à 1 15/16, l'Union Fon cière de 4 5/8 à 4 9/16 et la Zariffa de 3 1/4 4.2 3/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs la Spinning recule de 3/8 à 5/16, la Delta Land de 1 3/16 à 11/8, et la Levico de 3/8 à 5/16, tandis que les Markets reprennent de 26 à 26/6, et les Cot ton Mills de 2,6 à 2/9.
La Banque d'Orient est mieux tenue à 113.

Sur le reste il n'ya pas de changement à signaler, aucune affaire n'ayant été négociée. L'impression devient de jour en jour plus pessimiste. A ce sujet nous devons signaler qu'il y a de l'exagération dans la baisse comme il y en avait eu dans la hausse. Mais la nécessité n'admet pas de raisonnement. On s'est trop engagé ; il faut liquider.
Vile i Nungo endos Tos plus no
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET ORITIQUES

Le Caire, Jeudi 18 juillet. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres se maintient à 3 5/8 pour cent. Au Stock Ex change, le Consolidé anglais a réactionné hier de 1/8 S.S. 3/8. L'Unifiée est demeurée in changée à 101 1/2. La National Bank a encore baissé de 1/4 à 18 3/4. L'Agricole est restée invariée à 7 5/8, de même que la Daïra Sanieh À 13 3/8 et la Delta Light à 9 5/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a rétro gradé de 2 francs à 678, la Banque d'Athènes de 2 francs également à 113 et les Lots Turcs de 1 franc à 168.

Ainsi qu'il fallait s'y attendre, la tendance à la faiblesse s'est accentuée aujourd'hui sur notre marché des valeurs ; mais, comme nous le laisions observer dès bier, il n'y a toujours pas trace d'affolement ou de panique. Certes, les baissiers sont favorisés par un concours extraordinaire de circonstances et conservent indiscutablement le beau rôle ; mais ils n'en profitent guère, la stagnation battant son plein. Les offres trouvent de moins en moins les contre-parties ; la dépression ne s'exerce que grâce aux ventes forcées et aux exécutions, qui ne tarderont pas elles-mêmes à prendre forcément fin, étant donné que, tout compte fait, ce jeu de massacre est appelé à tourner 10, détriment des exécutants - qui auraient cout intérêt à attendre — plutôt qu'à celui les condamnés. Il n'en demeure pas moins que l'occasion est unique pour se former à bon :ompte d'excellents portefeuilles pour l'au
oine et l'hiver.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na cional a été ramenée jusqu'à 18 5/16 pour se elever à 18 1/2. L'Agricole a faibli à 7 1/2. La Banque d'Athènes est revenue à 112 et la Banqve d'Orient à 112 également.
Le Crédit Foncier a été délaissé à 680; l'o ligation à lots ancienne est tombée à 300. La Daira Sanich a perdu 1/8 à 13. L'Allotment a léchi & T 3,4-13/16 et sa part à 47.
La Delta Light s'est alourdie à 9 3/8. Les ouissances Eaux du Caire sont remontées à 80. Les Heliopolis ont faibli à 233. La Bras erie des Pyramides à 75, les Ciments à 27 et ? Sucreries à 48.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Idhgovich ont été offertes à 14 3/4. Les gyptian ont réactionne å 5 1/4-5/16. Les parts e fondateur National Hotels sont descendues 27. Les Ritz se sont raffermais à 019/16-5/8. Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land a beliela 1-3/16. Les Estates se sont tassés à 818-11/16 et leur part de fondateur a baissé £ 3. Les Salt and Soda ont faibli à 16 sh.
Khedivíal Mail A 20 sh. et les Construc ons à 0 5/16-3/8.
